wikipedia_page.main: Marjory Lees (9 September 1878 – 11 May 1970) was a British suffragist and local politician. Lees was active in the local women's movement in Oldham, Greater Manchester where she became the honorary secretary of the local branch of the National Union of Women Workers.

response: Lees died, aged 92, at Werneth Park, Oldham, on 14 April 1935. Her daughter, Marjory Lees (1878-1970), bequeathed the estate to the people of Oldham in 1936 to form the present public Werneth Park.

Recipients to date are: Dame Sarah Anne Lees, Dr Thomas Fawsitt, Alderman William Schofield, Charles Ward, Marjory Lees, Rt Hon Winston Leonard Spencer Churchill, Rt Hon JR Clynes, William E Freeman, James Bannon, Alderman Frank Tweedale, Thomas Driver, Alderman John Fletcher Waterhouse, the 41st (Oldham) Royal Tank Regiment TA, Sir William Turner Walton, Alice Amelia Kenyon, Charles Leslie Hale, Sir Frank lord, Dame Eva Turner, Arnold Tweedale OBE, 75 Engineer Regiment (Volunteers), Honorary Alderman Miss Ellen Brierley MBE, Sir Norman Kelvin Stoller CBE and Michael Hugh Meacher MP.
After the death of the philanthropist Dame Sarah Lees in 1936, her daughter, Miss Marjory Lees, donated the park to the town of Oldham.
